docs.text: Harmonic condition monitoring ¶ The tools and workflow described in these docs and hosted in the associated repositories on GitHub and Earth Engine are designed to support spatially and temporally consistent Landsat-based condition change monitoring for retrospective disturbance assessment at regional to national scales. Overview ¶ Detecting changes in surface conditions requires establishing reference or "baseline" conditions to be used for comparison. Our approach uses time series of Landsat observations to estimate a series of harmonic baseline models that account for seasonal variability in vegetation conditions and builds on previously published methods . This ensemble of harmonic models is used to estimate the average anomaly in Greenness for a given acquisition date. By then aggregating these average anomalies over a specified monitoring period (i.e. summer growing season), a relatively stable and robust annual estimate of change in Greenness can be produced. Spatial smoothing and thresholding by anomaly magnitude improves visualization of disturbance patches, and the resulting map products can be used to compare disturbances across years. Workflow ¶ Our workflow can be used to process Landsat time series and generate mean annual Tasseled Cap Greenness anomalies over large spatial extents using Google Earth Engine . Earth Engine users can add this repository with Reader access here . The scripts in this repository include: workflow_by_state/ 1S_v7_baseline_generator - Generate harmonic baseline models using fixed-length moving window (default: 5-year models) 2S_v7_predict_monitor - Estimate average Greenness anomalies for dates within monitoring period (default: May-September) 3S_v7_assessments_combine - Combine results across orbital Paths 4S_v7_visualization - Spatially smooth and threshold for visualization app/ APP_v7_disturbance_atlas - Interactive mapping App with select by year utils.js - Utility functions shared across scripts While these scripts are expected to provide a useful starting point for those seeking to replicate or build on our methods, users should carefully review all paths, inputs, and other parameter specifications in order to tune to their own study areas. Note: Current scripts have been developed and tested for US State geographies, and example products are available for a selection of Northeastern states within USFS Region 9.

docs.text: As proof of concept, we have piloted the harmonic baseline monitoring workflow for a selection of Northeastern states within USFS Region 9 and generated annual change assessments for 2010-2020 using a May 1 through September 30 monitoring period. To view these preliminary results, visit our Vegetation Disturbance Atlas App . For access to the datasets shown in this tool and any other questions, please join our Google Group here by clicking "Ask to Join Group".
docs.title: Vegetation Disturbance Atlas

docs.text: This script reads in monitoring results for individual Paths and generates a final wall-to-wall assessment product, resulting in a single map per year per state. Scores in Path overlap zones are combined by weighting based on number of observations (acquisitions) in the monitoring period. Output specifications ¶ Final assessment products are generated for the full coverage of the state ROI and are exported to specified Image Collection. setting description VERSION current version, 7-0 ROOT user repository folder RESULTS_COLLECTION monitoring results Image Collection OUTPUT_COLLECTION new assessment output Image Collection STATE USPS abbrev, e.g. MA OUTPUT_CRS ESPG code, e.g. 'EPSG:5070' Assessment Parameters ¶ The following parameters are used to generate monitoring results. Note: spectral index (DEPENDENT) is determined from baseline asset metadata. parameter type default explanation START_ASSESS int 2010 first year to generate assessment for END_ASSESS int 2020 last year to generate assessment for MIN_MONITOR_NOBS int 3 min num obs for valid monitoring MIN_RMSE_SCORE int -10 min average RMSE (for Path)

docs.text: This script generates harmonic baseline models for a user-specified Region of Interest, e.g. US State. Output specifications ¶ Baseline models are generated per Path and are exported to specified Image Collection. Current implementation exports Path imagery clipped to a US State boundary based on the TIGER: US Census States 2018 dataset . Specify state using two-letter USPS code, e.g. 'MA' for Massachusetts. setting description VERSION current version, 7-0 ROOT user repository folder BASELINES_COLLECTION new baselines Image Collection STATE USPS abbrev. e.g. MA Model parameters ¶ The following parameters are used to configure the baseline model runs. parameter type default explanation DEPENDENT string 'tcg' spectral index to use for model fitting HARMONICS string 'h13' harmonic frequencies: 'h12' or 'h13' START_YEAR int 1985 first year of first baseline END_YEAR int 2019 last year of last baseline WINDOW int 5 baseline length (moving window) TS string 'full' Landsat observations: 'full' or '16d' CC_THRESH int 80 maximum CLOUD_COVER_LAND filtering

docs.text: Our approach is based on the assumption that univariate time series of reflectance observations for a band or index of interest can be relatively well-characterized by a harmonic regression model. We use the following model form: where y t is the predicted vegetation index (e.g. Tasseled Cap Greenness), x t is the ordinal date of each observation; a 0 is the modeled intercept; b 0 is the modeled slope; N is a set of integers specifying the frequency, j , of the Fourier series harmonics (e.g. N = {1, 3}, corresponding to 12-month and 4-month harmonics); a j are the sine coefficients and b j are the cosine coefficients estimated at each frequency; T is the number of days in a year ( T = 365.25); and ε t is the residual error term for each observation. Condition Scores ¶ Condition scores are calculated by comparing observed reflectance values with baseline model predictions normalized by model Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE): A condition score can be calculated for each individual baseline model, and the current approach averages across an ensemble of predictions to generate a final estimate.

docs.text: This script reads a collection of baseline models and generates predictions and condition assessment scores by WRS2 Path for a user-specified monitoring period. Condition scores are averaged across N baseline models for each acquisition date, then mean scores are averaged over all acquisition dates in the monitoring period to produce a condition score estimate for each Path. Output specifications ¶ Monitoring results are generated per Path and are exported to specified Image Collection. setting description VERSION current version, 7-0 ROOT user repository folder BASELINES_COLLECTION baselines Image Collection OUTPUT_COLLECTION new monitoring output Image Collection STATE USPS abbrev. e.g. MA Monitoring parameters ¶ The following parameters are used to generate monitoring results. Note: spectral index (DEPENDENT) and harmonic frequencies (HARMONICS) are determined from baseline asset metadata. parameter type default explanation YEAR string 2020 monitoring year DAY_START string '05-01' start of monitoring period DAY_END string '09-30' end of monitoring period CC_THRESH int 80 maximum CLOUD_COVER_LAND filtering OBS_MIN int 30 exclude baselines with too few obs. N_MODELS int 5 number of models to ensemble

docs.text: This script is used to add spatially smoothed condition score products thresholded by magnitude to the map. Products for all years within the specified assessment range added at once, enabling inspection of cumulative change. Product specifications ¶ Final assessment products are visualized as spatially smoothed and magnitude-thresholded maps. setting description FINAL_PRODUCTS Image Collection with assessments by state Visualization Parameters ¶ The following parameters are used to map results. parameter type default explanation START_ASSESS int 2010 monitoring year END_ASSESS int 2020 start of monitoring period THRESHOLD int -2 condition score threshold
